document.docAuthor: Huang, Jia, Wang, Yalian, O’Grady, Patrick Michael, Su, Yirui & Chen, Hongwei
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

bibRefCitation.author: Duda, O.
bibRefCitation.refString: Duda, O. (1923) Die orientalischen und australischen Drosophiliden-Arten (Dipteren) des Ungarischen National-Museums zu Budapest. Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici, 20, 24 - 59.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species is most similar to
L . zebrina
sp. nov.
in having the mesonotum mostly brownish yellow ( Figs. 5H , 8Q ), the pleura with a brown, longitudinal stripe above ( Figs. 5I , 8R ), the wing slightly brownish along the tip of R 2+3 and dm-cu crossvein ( Figs. 2C , 4F ), and the shape and pubescence of epandrium, cercus, and surstylus ( Figs. 19A , 37A ), but can be distinguished from the latter by the colour patterns of abdominal tergites ( Fig. 9D, E ); paramere anteroventrally with a projection ( Fig. 19C ); aedeagus basolaterally with a small process, laterally with a long process at same its height; the long process bearing 2 sensilla at tip ( Fig. 19D ); see below for that species.

The specimens employed here are somewhat different from Duda’s (1923) descriptions of the only female holotype from Taiwan , China in the wing slightly brownish along the tip of R 2+3 and dm-cu crossvein ( Fig. 2C ), and the colour patterns of abdominal tergites ( Fig. 9D, E ). However, this is a “normal” species with numerous specimens. Moreover, some of these specimens were collected near the type locality. Therefore, all of the specimens were identified as
L . setipalpis
to avoid further confusion.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 19.
Leucophenga setipalpis Duda, 1923
, male terminalia in lateral view. A. Epandrium, surstylus, and cercus; B. Hypandrium, paramere, gonopods, aedeagus, and aedeagal apodeme; C. Paramere; D. Aedeagus. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.
